Author: Acura#2748
Content: They want to do Atomic swaps by Lightning.

Author: peddycb#5889
Content: Lightning Atomic swaps

Author: actionslacks#4072
Content: i had some back and forth w/them Q3 2019 is the hopium

Author: peddycb#5889
Content: would like to hear your opinion

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i tried that, but it isnt very efficient

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i implemented subatomic swaps, where you exchange a little bit at a time via a payment channel

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but you end up doing so many tx, it is slow and LN isnt exactly trustless for small payments

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: building on top of LN, it seems a very risky plan

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: people can barely get LN working for its intended usecase of micropayments

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: how they will make it work seamlessly for swaps, seems a mystery

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also what about coins without LN?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: who holds the keys during the swap?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: or maybe they use LN just for the broadcast network, which is quite an inefficient usage

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: tl:dr wait until they get something into beta release before believing they can get it to actually work

Author: peddycb#5889
Content: I just watch the project and want to learn what is good and evil

Author: KomodoWorld#8282
Content: I was reading about Stakenet today, hard to understand what it's based on. My understanding so far is that XSN masternodes act as full wallet for different coins, users have a light wallet. Masternodes are connected via LN, they do the order matching thing and trade between them. Users withdraw real coins when done. Seems an highly efficient proxy-token dex. I could be wrong though, details are scarce

Author: Acura#2748
Content:
I had a chat with one guy from xsn. 
Asked him how i need xsn ?
 For which reason ?
This he answered to me:

Primary:

Payment of all fees (onchain tx, offchain tx, lightning swap fee).
Burn verification of dApps.
Payment of DB and CPU renting.

But you don't have to own xsn to do this. For example, if you want to pay a merchant with LTC who only accepts BTC LN payments, you can do this with LTC thanks to LN swaps and the swap fees are calculated in the backend with XSN and deducted over a separate LN swap without you noticing.

We migrate all LN features into our MN layer (channel funding, facotry channels, watchtowers, swap resolver, ...). Consequently, the MN operators are also those who benefit from most of the fees. On the other hand they have to run potent hardware to host the fullnodes with multiple blockchains or dapps.

Translated with www.DeepL.com/Translator

Author: Acura#2748
Content: MN = Masternode

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it is a custodial process where all MN become money transmittors

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: good luck with that

Author: Acura#2748
Content: üòÑ

Content: "Masternodes are connected via LN, they do the order matching thing and trade between them"

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so they have LN there for the buzzword value, not technical

Author: KomodoWorld#8282
Content: found an article w more details: https://medium.com/stakenet/xsn-2018-roadmap-ccpos-part-2-548d27958ebb  yes the MN are connected via LN and act as watchtowers. No much details on how users funds are secured, my best guess it's in fact a proxy token system

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: @jl777c i read something recently about some devs adding a vault, whereby the BTC is sent to a special address. Then once a tx is created to use that utxo, the owner has x amount of time to VETO a tx basically. Dont know how it is supposed to work but would something like that work with KMD?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://www.coindesk.com/the-vault-is-back-bitcoin-coder-to-revive-plan-to-shield-wallets-from-theft

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: requires constant monitoring, special GUI

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: seems not a big project

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: Do you know how they can stop someone with your private keys from spending it with a higher fee?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think it is a bit like atomic swap, some clever scripting to allow vaulting

Author: KomodoWorld#8282
Content: months ago I talked with @mrlynch about developing a CC for a bounty from me, based on the original Vault paper by prof. Sirer, but it's still far from completed

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: Will be interesting to learn how this is done

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: Under Bishop‚Äôs proposal, if an ‚Äúunlock period‚Äù were initiated, an owner could choose to react or not react.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it is like atomic swap timeout, with yourself

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: But if someone has your private key, how does the blockchain know who is the owner? üòõ

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you send funds to a p2sh address that requires an unlock utxo that is matured

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so there is another special utxo that needs to be spent first, the spending of this starts the unlock period

Author: hyperDEX#6586
Content: So maybe they are thinking about it the wrong way, the default should be not to send and if you are sending a valid tx then you send that through

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think ALL spends need to go through this, so if a one day delay, then all access to these funds will take a day

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in the event you see the unlocking txid activated, you have one day to spend (with a different privkey?) the original funds, which are still in the conditional p2sh

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: something like that

Content: if you can find the design document that he posted wherever, i can look at it and see how hard it is to do
